ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text cannot be read meaningfully.
Text contains some simple readable content with limited response to audience needs.
Text can be read and provides some information to support reader understanding.
Persuasive text is internally consistent and contains sufficient information for the reader to follow it fairly easily.
Persuasive text supports reader understanding and begins to engage the reader.
Persuasive text supports, engages and persuades the reader through deliberate choice of language and use of persuasive techniques.
Persuasive text persuades the reader through precise and sustained choice of language and use of persuasive devices.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The writer’s capacity to orient, engage and affect the reader

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: No evidence of any structural components of a persuasive text.
Minimal evidence of persuasive structure; for example, structural components not clearly identifiable or one component only.
All three structural features (introduction, body and conclusion) exist but are not fully developed, or one feature is missing.
All structural features exist (introduction, body and conclusion) and are developed, or a longer, sophisticated text is presented with one weaker component.

Coherent, controlled and complete argument, including an introduction with clear position statement, body with reasons and detailed supporting evidence, and a conclusion that reinforces the writer's position.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The organisation of text features including introduction, body and conclusion into an appropriate and effective text structure.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has insufficient evidence of ideas.
Ideas are very few and very simple; or appear unrelated to each other or unrelated to the prompt.
One idea with simple elaboration; or ideas are few and related but not elaborated; or ideas are many, simple and related but not elaborated.
Ideas are supported with some elaboration or unelaborated ideas relate plausibly to argument.
Ideas are elaborated and contribute effectively to the writer's position.
Ideas are generated, selected and crafted to be highly persuasive.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The creation, selection and crafting of ideas for a Persuasive text.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has insufficient evidence of persuasive devices.
Uses a statement or statements of personal opinion or uses one or two instances of persuasive devices.
Uses three or more instances of persuasive devices that support the writer’s position (at least two types).
Uses some devices that persuade. Use is effective but not sustained, meaning approximately one page (may also include some ineffective use).
Sustained and effective use of persuasive devices.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The use of a range of persuasive devices to enhance a writer's position and persuade the reader.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has insufficient evidence of vocabulary.
Very short script with few content words.
Words in the text are mostly simple verbs, adverbs, adjectives and/or nouns, but may include two or three precise words or word groups.
Four or more precise words or word groups.
Sustained & consistent use of words & word groups that enhance the meaning (may be some inappropriate or inaccurate word choices).
Text contains sustained and consistent use of precise, effective words and word groups used in a natural and articulate manner.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The range and precision of language choices.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has insufficient evidence of cohesion.
Cohesive links are missing or incorrect, making the text very confusing to a reader, or text is very short with limited evidence.
Text has some correct cohesive links between sentences. Most reference words are accurate. A reader may occasionally need to re-read the text and provide their own links to clarify meaning.
Text has cohesive devices used correctly to support reader understanding, and accurate use of referring words such that meaning is clear and the text flows well in a sustained piece of writing.
A range of cohesive devices is used correctly and deliberately to enhance reading an extended, highly cohesive piece of writing, showing continuity of ideas and tightly linked sections of text.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The control of multiple threads and relationships over the whole text, achieved through the use of referring words, substitutions, word associations and text connectives.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has no correct use of paragraphs or attempted use is random.
Text has at least one correct paragraph break and is organised into paragraphs that are mainly focused on a single idea or set of like ideas that assist the reader to digest chunks of text.
Text has all paragraphs focused on one idea or set of like ideas. At least one paragraph is logically constructed and contains a topic sentence and supporting detail. Paragraphs are mostly correct.
Paragraphing supports argument. Paragraphs are ordered and cumulatively build argument across text.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The segmenting of text into paragraphs that assists the reader to negotiate the text.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has no evidence of sentences.
Very limited control of sentence formation, with some correct formation of sentences, such that some meaning can be construed.
Correct sentences are mostly simple and/or compound, and meaning is predominantly clear.
Most simple and compound sentences are correct, with some correct use of complex sentences. Meaning is predominantly clear.
Most simple, compound and complex sentences are correct or all simple, compound and complex sentences are correct but sentences do not demonstrate variety. Meaning is clear.

Sentences are correct, allowing for an occasional slip in more sophisticated structures, and demonstrate variety. Text contains controlled and well-developed sentences that express precise meaning and are consistently effective.
Text contains correct, well controlled and well developed sentences that express precise meaning and are consistently effective.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The production of grammatically correct, structurally sound and meaningful sentences.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has no evidence of correct sentence punctuation.
Text has minimal punctuation that is of little assistance to a reader.
Text has some correct punctuation that assists a reader.

Text has punctuation that is adequate to assist the reader. Most sentences are correctly punctuated with capital letters and full stops. The text shows some correct use of other punctuation such as commas or apostrophes.

Text has accurate punctuation that enables smooth and efficient reading. All sentences are correctly punctuated with capital letters and full stops, and text shows correct use of most other necessary punctuation.
Text has punctuation that provides precise markers to pace and control reading. Text contains accurate use of all applicable punctuation.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The use of correct and appropriate punctuation to aid reading of the text.

ScoreDescription.Descriptor: Text has no conventional spelling or consists of text that is copied from the stimulus material.
Text has few examples of conventional spelling, or is very short with limited evidence.
Text has correct spelling of most simple words, and some common words. There may also be errors evident in common words.
Text has correct spelling of most simple words and most common words.
Text has correct spelling of most simple words, most common words and some difficult words.
Text has correct spelling of simple words, most common words, and at least 10 difficult words.
Text has correct spelling of all words, and at least 10 difficult words and some challenging words, or at least 15 difficult words if no challenging words.

NAPWritingRubric.Descriptor: The accuracy of spelling and the difficulty of the words used.
